steps.title: Buy or gather some raw, unsalted, hulled sunflower seeds.
steps.content: Buy or gather some raw, unsalted, hulled sunflower seeds. Hulled sunflower seeds — those without shells — will sprout more quickly. If you can only gather unhulled sunflower seeds, collect these in a bowl and allow them to soak overnight. In the morning, toss the seeds then pour them into a strainer. Try to pick out hulls as you go. Do not worry if some hulls remain.

steps.title: Place the seeds in a jar.
steps.content: Place the seeds in a jar. Place the sunflower seeds in a large, open-mouth jar such as a canning jar or something slightly larger.

steps.title: Add water.
steps.content: Add water. Fill the jar with water so that the seeds float on top.

steps.title: Allow the jar to sit for about eight hours.
steps.content: Allow the jar to sit for about eight hours. During this period, the seeds should begin to sprout. Wait until the seeds have nearly doubled in size and the sprout has begun to emerge. When sprouting sunflower seeds, always periodically check them so that you do not allow them to soak for too long.

steps.title: Rinse and return them to the jar.
steps.content: Rinse and return them to the jar. Make sure to cover the jar again.

steps.title: Wait.
steps.content: Wait. Let them sit in the jar, in a warm or room temperature location with no direct sunlight, for one to three days until they've finished sprouting. Rinse them and return them to the jar one or two times a day until they are done. You can also use a special sprouting bag instead of the original jar. Place the sprouting seeds into the sprouting bag and hang it over a sink or other area to allow draining. Continue to rinse every five hours or so.

steps.title: Enjoy!
steps.content: Enjoy! When they've started to sprout and look like little V's, they're ready to eat. Rinse the sprouts you plan to eat and store the remaining sprouts in your refrigerator to enjoy later.

steps.title: Get your supplies.
steps.content: Get your supplies. You'll need black oil sunflower seeds, glass pie dishes (at least two), and some healthy soil from your local garden store (preferably organic).

steps.title: Make your sprouting area.
steps.content: Make your sprouting area. Take one of your glass pie dishes and fill it with soil until it is just below the crust lip.

steps.title: Soak your seeds.
steps.content: Soak your seeds. Take a 1/4 cup of seeds and soak them in a bowl of water, completely covered in water, for 8 hrs.

steps.title: Add the seeds to the soil.
steps.content: Add the seeds to the soil. Spread the seeds across the soil and then water them thoroughly.

steps.title: Place the second pie dish on top of the soil.
steps.content: Place the second pie dish on top of the soil. Place the bottom surface of the second pie plate on top of the soil, as if you were nesting the plates. Press down and drain the excess water.

steps.title: Wait.
steps.content: Wait. Store your sprouting seed (with the second pie dish still on top) in a warm, dark place. Wait about three days, but check on them every day. When the upper plate is lifted about an inch, remove it from the dark place.

steps.title: Place them in the sun.
steps.content: Place them in the sun. Remove the upper plate and place the sprouts in a sunny location.

steps.title: Eat them when they're ready.
steps.content: Eat them when they're ready. When they're ready to be eaten, cut the sprouts and rinse them to get rid of the shells. From the time you take them into the sun, it takes roughly another two days for them to be ready to eat. Shorter if it's very warm where you live. Try them in salads, sushi, soup, or sandwiches. Enjoy!

steps.title: Consider sprouting or growing greens.
steps.content: Consider sprouting or growing greens. Either method will work for germinating sunflowers for planting, but you can also use the traditional plant germinating method that follows. Sunflowers are notoriously difficult to get to grow straight in their final location and are a favorite snack for birds. Sprouting them before planting might improve your chances of keeping them alive.

steps.title: Soak some paper towels.
steps.content: Soak some paper towels. Mist several paper towels in water with a bit of plant food mixed in. The towels should be wet but not soaked and difficult to handle. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Place seeds in the towel.
steps.content: Place seeds in the towel. Place a couple of seeds in the towel with space between them and fold the paper towel up so that they are covered.

steps.title: Place the paper towel in a plastic bag.
steps.content: Place the paper towel in a plastic bag. Give the paper towel a few more drops of water and place it in a resealable plastic bag (such as a Zip-loc bag). Seal it most of the way, with just a small, ~1" gap at the center.

steps.title: Set in the sunlight.
steps.content: Set in the sunlight. Set the bag in the sunlight and give the seeds time to germinate.

steps.title: Plant when they are ready.
steps.content: Plant when they are ready. Plant when they have sprouted, making sure to place them in soil with a pH between 6.5 and 7. Sunflowers need full sunlight to grow. Consider planting them along a fence or your house, or behind some sturdy trees, to shield them from the wind. Keep in mind that sunflowers planted in pots will not grow as big as sunflowers planted in the ground. Sunflowers are drought-tolerant, but you should ensure they get plenty of water while they establish their roots. They can also survive in wet, humid weather, but you will need to make sure they are planted in well-draining soil, like a sand or loam mixture. [2] X Research source
